ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Thermal and structural characterization of Cu–Al–Mn–X (Ti, Ni) shape memory alloys

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Physics, Faculty of Science
Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this study, the Cu–Al–Mn–X (X = Ni, Ti) shape memory alloys at the range of 10–12 at.% of aluminum and 4–5 at.% manganese were produced by arc melting. We have investigated the effects of the alloying elements on the transformation temperatures, and the structural and the magnetic properties of the quaternary Cu–Al–Mn–X (X = Ni, Ti) shape memory alloys. The evolution of the transformation temperatures was studied by differential scanning calorimetry with different heating and cooling rates. The characteristic transformation temperatures and the thermodynamic parameters were highly sensitive to variations in the aluminum and manganese content, and it was observed that the nickel addition into the Cu–Al–Mn system decreased the transformation temperature although Ti addition caused an increase in the transformation temperatures. The effect of the nickel and the titanium on the thermodynamic parameters such as enthalpy and entropy values was investigated. The structural changes of the samples were studied by X-ray diffraction measurements and by optical microscope observations at room temperature. It is evaluated that the element Ni has been completely soluble in the matrix, and the main phase of the Cu–Al–Mn–Ni sample is martensite, and due to the low solubility of the Ti, the Cu–Al–Mn–Ti sample has precipitates, and a martensite phase at room temperature. The magnetic properties of the Cu–Al–Mn, Cu–Al–Mn–Ni and Cu–Al–Mn–Ti samples were investigated, and the effect of the nickel and the titanium on the magnetic properties was studied.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The martensitic transformation is a diffusionless phase transition in the solid state. In this transformation, the atoms keep on moving comparatively in regard to their neighbours. The thermoelastic martensitic transformations are responsible for the shape change from martensite to the austenite phase or from austenite to martensite phase (M↔A) in the shape memory alloys (SMAs). The phase change process occurred in these materials, which was obtained repeatedly on cooling and heating. In this respect, the shape memory effect is linked from an ordered austenite phase (β-phase) to the martensite phase [1, 2].

With the development of the technology, the SMAs have been considered as a possible alternative to the traditional materials because of their excellent properties such as shape memory effect (SME), pseudoelasticity (PE), low manufacturing cost and their advantages with regard to the electrical and thermal conductivities [3]. Among the shape memory alloy systems, the Cu–Al binary systems are paid conspicuous attention to by researchers in the SMA research field [4–7]. However, the Cu–Al-based SMAs have high elastic anisotropy leading to poor mechanical properties, easy intercrystalline failure and the short fatigue cycle life. In recent years, many studies have been carried out in order to improve the properties of Cu–Al systems by adding other elements such as Mn, Ni and Be [8]. The addition of the Mn to the binary Cu–Al system has resulted in enhanced ductility, which is very important for practical applications [9]. In the Cu–Al–Mn SMAs, the low aluminum and the high manganese content showed good ductility and SME. Actually, the low aluminum content has remarkably improved the degree of long range order, and exhibited a thermoelastic martensitic transformation with accompanying SME and PE [10–12]. The Cu–Al–Mn ternary SMA system has a disordered structure at high temperature. During quenching, the alloy has showed the ordering transitions β(A2) → β
2 (B2) → β
1 (L21), and then the thermoelastic martensitic transformation has occurred as β
1 (L21) →
(9R or 18R). In addition to that, the Cu–Al–Mn alloys have also displayed interesting magnetic properties, and these magnetic properties with SME were studied [13–16].

The objective of this research is to study the effect of the quaternary elements on the Cu–Al–Mn ternary system. For this purpose, the Cu–Al–Mn–X (X = Ni, Ti) alloys were fabricated, and thermal and structural observations were made to determine the effect of the Ni and Ti addition on the Cu–Al–Mn ternary system. The variation of the characteristic transformation temperatures, the order–disorder phase transitions and the thermodynamic parameters were investigated with the change of the alloying element in the matrix. In this work, the Ni and Ti were selected due to the solubility of these elements in the Cu-matrix, and one of the aims is to examine the evolutions in the microstructure and the distribution of Ni and Ti in the matrix.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
The Cu–Al–Mn–X (X = Ni, Ti at.%) samples were produced by ingot metallurgy. The high purity elements Cu, Al, Mn, Ni and Ti (99.99 %) were mixed for the homogenization of the elements for 3 h and then made as pellets. The pellets of each sample were melted under argon atmosphere by an Edmund Buehler Arc Melter between 12–24 V and 75–150 A. The compositions of the fabricated alloys are given in Table 1. The obtained alloys were cut from the cast ingot in dimensions of 3 mm × 3 mm × 1.5 mm as small pieces. The small pieces of the alloys were solution-treated at 1123 K for 1 h, and quenched in the iced-brine water to obtain
martensite. The chemical composition of the alloys were determined by using a Bruker Model energy dispersive X-ray (EDX). For the characterization of the alloys, different methods were used. Transformation characteristics of the specimens were determined by Shimadzu DSC-60A differential scanning calorimetry with different heating and cooling rates. The TG/DTA (Shimadzu TA-60 WS) measurements were performed from room temperature to 1373 K at a heating rate of 20 K/min to identify order–disorder phase transitions at high temperatures. Phase identification was performed in a Rigaku RadB-DMAX II diffractometer with CuKα radiation to inform the diffraction planes at room temperature. For the optical micrograph observations, the surface layers of the samples were cleaned by an etching solution of (FeCl3·6H2O)–methanol with HCl, and the optical microstructure observations were made by using a Nikon MA200 model optical metallographic microscope. Magnetic measurements were carried out by Quantum Design PPMS (Model 6000) in order to investigate the behaviors of the field-induced martensitic transformation.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were made with different heating/cooling rates (5, 15, 25, 35 and 45 K/min), and are shown in Figs. 1, 2 and 3 for CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples, respectively. For the determination of the alloying element on the transformation temperatures, the DSC curves of all the CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples with a heating/cooling rate of 25 K/min are shown in Fig. 4.
Fig. 1
DSC curves of the CAM sample with different heating/cooling rates (5, 15, 25, 35, 45 K/min)
Fig. 2
DSC curves of the CAMN sample with different heating/cooling rates (5, 15, 25, 35, 45 K/min)
Fig. 3
DSC curves of the CAMT sample with different heating/cooling rates (5, 15, 25, 35, 45 K/min)
Fig. 4
DSC curves of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT SMAs with a heating/cooling rate of 25 K/min

The characteristic austenite and martensite transformation temperatures A s, A f, M s and M f were determined by the tangent method, and the obtained data is given in Table 2. The endothermic peak on the DSC heating curve is associated with the austenite transformation, and the exothermic peak on the DSC cooling curve indicates the martensite transformation. The reverse and forward transformations exhibit a typical thermoelastic feature with a temperature hysteresis (A f–M s) of 30–72 K (Fig. 5). Hysteresis (A f–M s) values and the maximum peak temperature in reverse transformation (A max) are given in Table 2. The CAMN sample has the lowest transformation hysteresis value, and the CAM sample has the highest transformation hysteresis value. This behavior can be explained with the effect of nickel and titanium in the sample. The thermal hysteresis values of each sample indicate a dependence on heating/cooling rates although the enthalpy value is slightly dependent on heating/cooling rates (Table 2). Generally, in the Cu–Al–Mn SMAs, both Al and Mn have affected the transformation temperatures, but the effect of aluminum is greater than that of manganese [14]. The effect of the Ni in CAMN and the Ti in CAMT must be considered on the transformation characteristics. The M s temperature also depends on the composition in the Cu–Al–Mn–X quaternary alloys. Ni has a high solubility and decreases the M s temperature in Cu–Al–Mn system. Due to the low solubility of Ti, Ti increases the M s temperature. While considering the effects of the alloying elements on transformation temperatures, the increase of the Al and Mn contents in the sample decreases the M s temperature [17–20]. The thermal parameters such as enthalpy, entropy and hysteresis values are decreased with the addition of Ni and Ti when compared with the Cu–Al–Mn alloy.

Effect of heating and cooling rates on temperature hysteresis

Thermal parameters such as enthalpy, entropy and T 0 equilibrium temperature values determined from DSC analysis with different heating/cooling rates are given in Table 2. The equilibrium temperature between the martensite and austenite phases according to Salzbrenner and Cohen is determined by the following relation [21]; 1
$$ T_{ 0} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {M_{\text{s}} + A_{\text{f}} } \right) $$
T 0
=
1 2
M s
+
A f
where M s is the martensite start temperature, A f is the austenite finish temperature. The entropy change during the reverse transformation can be determined by the following equation [22, 23]; 2
$$ \Delta S_{{{\text{M}} \to A}} = \frac{{\Delta H_{{{\text{M}} \to A}} }}{{T_{ 0} }}, $$
Δ
S
M → A
=
Δ
H
M → A
T 0
,
where ΔS is the entropy change, ΔH is the enthalpy change, and T 0 is the equilibrium temperature. DSC curves during heating and cooling were integrated as a function of temperature, so the enthalpy value is determined from the total area of the peak from M → A or A → M transformations.

The characteristic transformation temperatures obtained from DSC peaks are used to determine the kinetic parameters such as the activation energy. The activation energy can vary certainly with the temperature, so different heating rates are used to determine the activation energy for the reverse transformation. The activation energies of CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples were calculated according to the Augis–Bennett method. The curves of ln (β/T
x − T) versus 1000/T
x for the samples are given in Fig. 6. The results are processed by the following equation [24];
Fig. 6
Activation energy curves of CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples
3
$$ \ln \left[ {\frac{\beta }{{T_{x} - T}}} \right] = \frac{{E_{a} }}{{R \times T_{x} }} + {\text{const}}, $$
ln
β
T x
- T
=
E a
R ×
T x
+ const ,
where β is the heating rate, T
x is the maximum temperature of the DSC peak in reverse transformation, and T is the onset of crystallization temperature, R is the universal gas constant and E is the activation energy. The calculated activation energy values of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples are 270.76, 6.06 and 30.34 kJ/mol, respectively.

The differential thermal analysis measurements (TG/DTA) were performed from room temperature to 1373 K with a heating rate of 20 K/min. The TG/DTA curves seen in Fig. 7 show the phase transitions of CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples. The matrixes of the alloys are based on Cu, Al and Mn, so the general behavior of this Cu–Al–Mn ternary system strongly affects the behavior of the CAMN and CAMT samples, and the transition temperatures increase with the decrease of the Al content. The samples show three phase transitions with the increase of temperature, and these transitions are described as β (A2) → β
2 (B2) → β
1 (L21) [2, 17, 18]. The transformation steps observed in CAM, CAMN and CAMT can be explained as:
1.
A2 → B2 transition (CsCl type ordered).
2.
B2 → L21 transition (Cu2MnAl type ordered).
3.
L21 → 9R or 18R transition.
Fig. 7
TG/DTA curves of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT SMAs with a heating/cooling rate of 20 K/min

The B2 → L21 transition occurred near the eutectoid temperature, and the peak observed 1200–1350 K is due to the liquefaction of the samples. The endothermic peaks observed below 500 K belong to the reverse transformation temperatures observed in the DSC measurements.

The effect of Ni and Ti on the ternary Cu–Al–Mn system was investigated from structural observations. With this aim, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CAM, CAMN and CAMT were taken at room temperature, and are shown in Fig. 8. As seen in Fig. 8, the samples exhibit a superlattice reflection, and the calculated a/b ratio for the samples is 0.86.
Fig. 8
X-ray diffraction patterns of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT SMAs

This result confirms that the structures of the samples are monoclinic, and the parent phase of each sample has a long period stacking order structure. Although the main diffraction peaks of the samples are the same, some changes such as peak cleaves and peak expansions were observed in the samples with the addition of the nickel and titanium. The nickel and titanium addition also changed the morphology and the diffraction planes of the samples as mentioned in Mallik et al. [2, 14, 18]. The main diffraction peaks of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples are (122), (0022), (1210) and (2012), which belong to the
martensite phase at room temperature. The (202) and (1210) diffraction planes, which were observed in CAM and CAMN samples, disappeared in the CAMT sample. This is mainly due to the effect of the Ti addition into the Cu–Al–Mn ternary system. The diffraction pattern of the CAMT sample became wide as observed at 2θ = 45°. The broadening of the (2012) peak for CAMT sample is due to the low solubility of Ti in the matrix. The addition of Ti into Cu–Al–Mn caused the formation of a precipitate phase in the alloy and this precipitate phase has diffraction planes, which were present in the structure at room temperature, and not decomposed from the (2012) diffraction plane.

The average crystallite size (D) for each sample was determined by the Debye–Scherrer equation [25, 26]. 4
$$ D\, = \,\frac{0.9\lambda }{{B_{{{{\text{l}} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\text{l}} 2}} \right. \kern-0pt} 2}}} \cos \theta }} ,$$
D
=
0.9 λ
B
l
l 2
2
cos θ
,
where λ is the wavelength of the X-ray (CuKα radiation), B is the peak full width at half maximum, and θ is the Bragg angle. The calculated crystallite size of the CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples are 21.53, 19.1 and 26.93 nm, respectively. Figure 9 shows the optical micrographs of the Cu–Al–Mn sample and the samples with quaternary additions. The martensite variants in CAM and CAMN samples are clearly observed, but the orientations of these martensite variants are different. It is confirmed from the micrographs that the element Ni was completely soluble in the matrix, and the main phase of the CAMN sample at the room temperature is martensite. The martensite formation in the CAMT sample has precipitates, and this is mainly due to the low solubility of Ti. Also, this forms precipitates in the matrix in martensite phase at the room temperature. The solubility limit of the alloying elements in the Cu-main phase is varied with the temperature, so the solubility of the added elements in the Cu-main phase is varied and forms precipitates at the room temperature. This variation has also affected the composition of the alloying elements and at the same time the transformation temperatures of the fabricated alloys [27, 28].
Fig. 9
Optical micrographs of CAM, CAMN and CAMT SMAs

Figure 10 shows the M–H loops of the samples taken at the room temperature between the −5 and 5 T magnetic field. It is seen from the curves that the CAM, CAMN and CAMT samples represent paramagnetic properties. The samples show magnetization when the magnetic field is applied. However, the samples have no magnetization when the magnetic field is removed. Additionally, Ni is ferromagnetic, and this property has increased the slope of the magnetization curve according to CAM and CAMT samples, as shown in Fig. 10.
Fig. 10
M–H curves of CAM, CAMN and CAMT SMAs

ItemContent.Para: The effect of the quaternary element addition on the transformation temperatures, thermodynamic parameters such as enthalpy, entropy and (A f–M s) hysteresis values of the Cu–Al–Mn SMA was investigated. Both the addition of Ni and Ti decreases the enthalpy, entropy and hysteresis values of the Cu–Al–Mn system.

The addition of the quaternary elements Ni and Ti into the Cu–Al–Mn system also changes the austenite and martensite transformation temperatures. When we compare the effect of Ni and Ti on Cu–Al–Mn ternary system, Ni has balanced the effect of Al and Mn in CAMN sample, so the A s and M s temperatures are low according to the CAM sample. On the other hand, the CAMT sample has high transformation temperatures (A s and M s) according to CAM and CAMN. This can be explained by the compositions of the elements in the sample and the low solubility of Ti in the matrix.

The order–disorder transitions for the samples in the β-phase have been determined. It has been observed that the ordering transition temperatures are strongly influenced by the Al content rather than by the Mn content. On the other hand, the quaternary elements Ni and Ti have also affected the L21 → 9R or 18R transition temperatures.

XRD measurements and the optical micrograph analysis have supported each other. The samples have a martensite structure at room temperature. In the CAMN sample, Ni was completely soluble in the matrix, but in the CAMT sample, Ti has a low solubility and forms precipitates in the matrix.
